Zhengzhou Institute of Emerging Industrial Technology Zhengzhou Henan 450000 China Polymeric ionic liquid membranes (PILMs) were prepared by photo-initiated polymerization of DMAEMA-based ionic liquids (ILs) and co-monomers for the conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates. The influences of functional groups and anions were investigated to find the optimal ionic liquid monomer. The PILM based on [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br exhibited the highest propyl carbonate (PC) yield (98%), which was close to that of the [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br monomer. Moreover, the PILMs can catalyze the gas state propylene oxide (PO) and CO2 into PC with a PO conversion of 87.3%, while the PO conversion of the pure polymeric ionic liquids was only 3.1% for gas state PO. The excellent catalytic activity can be attributed to the highly active catalytic sites and superb swelling ability of PILMs. The dry PILMs could absorb the PO vapor and swell into membranes with abundant pores, which contained plentiful active sites to catalyze PO and CO2 to PC efficiently. Graphical abstract As can be seen in the Figure that the Polymeric ionic liquid membranes (PILMs) can catalyze the gas state propylene oxide (PO) and CO2 into PC with a PO conversion of 87.3%, while the PO conversion of the pure polymeric ionic liquids was only 3.1% for gas state PO. The excellent catalytic activity can be attributed to the highly active catalytic sites and superb swelling ability of PILMs. The dry PILMs could absorb the PO vapor and swell into membranes with abundant pores, which contained plentiful active sites to catalyze PO and CO2 to PC efficiently. Nomenclature Abbreviations ACP absorption-conversion process DMAEMA 2-(dimethylamino) ethyl methacrylate EO ethylene oxide GLR gas-liquid reaction IL ionic liquid ILs ionic liquids PILs polymeric ionic liquids PILMs polymeric ionic liquid membranes PC propylene carbonate PO propylene oxide PVP polyvinyl pyrrolidone Introduction Chemical conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) into high commercial value products is one of the attractive and economic-beneficial means for chemical enterprises to utilize the CO2 in industrial exhausts [1–4]. Among the many CO2 conversion strategies, CO2 reacts with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates (Scheme 1 ) is one of the most economically feasible processes to convert CO2 [3,5–7]. In this route, the CO2 and epoxides can be 100% utilized. The product cyclic carbonates are a kind of high valuable solvents and chemical feedstocks, which are widely used in chemical synthesis, extraction, and dyeing [8]. The cyclic carbonates can further react with methanol to produce dimethyl carbonate (DMC), which is an important solvent in electrolytes for Li-ion batteries [9]. Since the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides was first discovered at IG Farben in 1943 [10], various catalysts were developed for this reaction, including alkali salts [11–14], metallic oxide [15–18], organometallic complexes [19–21], ionic liquids (ILs) [22–24], etc. Due to the application of high active catalysts, the reaction condition of this high-activation-energy reaction was reduced from ∼200 °C and ∼10 MPa to 30 °C and 0.1 MPa [5,18]. Among these catalysts, ILs show greater potential for the large-scale conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates, owing to the excellent features of ILs, such as high designability, highly active microenvironment of cation and anion, high stability, etc. In the recent over ten years, a series of ILs have been used to catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides and CO2, including quaternary ammonium, quaternary phosphonium, imidazolium, and other new kinds of ILs [25–28]. Park et al. [29] use quaternary ammonium ILs to catalyze the synthesis of cyclic carbonates, and they found that the large cations decreased the constraint of halogen anions, which facilitated the leaving ability of anions. Sun et al. proposed a series of hydroxyl‑functionalized ILs to catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides, which showed higher activity and selectivity, due to the synergistic effect of the OH-functional group in cations and nucleophilic anions [30]. Meng et al. [5] synthesized a series of high-active DUB-based ILs (1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec‑7-ene, DBU), which could catalyze epoxides and CO2 at room temperature and barometric pressure. Although homogeneous ILs exhibit higher catalytic activity, the high energy consumption and complexity of the catalyst recovery process hinder the green and low-energy-consumption development of CO2 conversion [31,32]. Hence, a series of ILs-based heterogeneous catalysts were developed to overcome this problem, including supported ILs [33–36], confined ILs [8,37,38], and polymeric ionic liquids (pILs) [39–41]. Due to the advantages such as easy preparation, high concentration of catalytic sites, and easy recyclability, pILs have been attracting growing attention in recent years [42]. However, the common pILs based on vinyl imidazole usually suffer from a severe activity decline compared with the corresponding monomers [40]. Ying et al. [42] proposed a series of novel pILs based on 2-(dimethylamino) ethyl methacrylate (DMAEMA), which presented catalytic activity close to the IL monomers. The excellent performance of DMAEMA-based pILs can be attributed to two factors. On the one hand, the ester group and long carbon chain could separate the OH-functional groups to prevent the over aggregation of active sites. On the other, the pILs were prepared in a very low concentration solution of monomers to obtain polymer aggregates smaller than 110 nm (in water), and the size of the pIL aggregates reduced as the temperature increased. These two factors resulted in a quasi-homogeneous process, which can significantly increase the efficiency of the reaction. Nevertheless, these could also lead to the partial dissolution of the pILs in epoxides/(cyclic carbonates), which could decrease the recyclability of pILs. Moreover, the pILs were quite hygroscopic and became gel-like when the water content was high. Therefore, Ying et al. [43] further grafted the pILs onto silica for a better application in industry. However, the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides using pILs catalyst, as well as other ILs-based heterogeneous catalysts, is still a typical gas-liquid reaction (GLR), as shown in Fig. 1 (left). It means that the CO2 needs to dissolve in the epoxides/carbonates at first, and then the dissolved CO2 needs to contact the pILs via diffusion or stirring. The CO2 solubility and the distribution of pILs in epoxide/carbonate both greatly influence the reaction rate. If the pILs were made into porous materials and contacted with the gas phase sufficiently, the Gas-Liquid reaction process could turn into an absorption-conversion process (ACP). As shown in Fig. 1(right), the CO2 and propylene oxide (PO, for instance) could be absorbed/adsorbed into the pores in pILs [44], and then converted into propylene carbonate (PC) rapidly, due to the abundant high-active pILs chain/network in pores. In the GLR, the pILs were sparsely distributed in the liquid. While in the ACP, the pILs were concentrated into porous materials, forming innumerable high-active microenvironments to promote the high-efficient reaction of CO2 and epoxides, even without the agitation [45]. Many ILs-based porous materials had been developed, such as ILs-grafted inorganic porous materials, porous polymer-supported ILs, confined ILs, and so on. Among these materials, ILs-based catalytic membranes have drawn more and more researchers’ attention, since they could combine the catalytic reaction process and membrane separation process, which may raise the reaction efficiency and simplify the production process [46–48]. For example, Keraani et al. [49] immobilize an ionically tagged Hoveyda catalyst in supported ionic liquid membranes (SILMs) to catalyze olefin metathesis reaction in a membrane reactor. Gu et al. [50] prepared a high active PES membrane containing pILs and palladium nanoparticles to catalyze the Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction. For the cycloaddition reaction of ethylene oxide (EO), the application of a catalytic membrane may significantly increase production efficiency and reduce energy consumption. Because catalytic membrane may directly catalyze the low concentration EO in the gas mixture of the ethylene oxidation process, and realize the reaction and separation of CO2 and EO in one step. The combination of reaction and separation could simplify the purification of EO, which is a complicated and energy-intensive process [51]. However, due to the high reactivity of EO, the reported membranes and commercial membranes were unstable and not applicable for industrial applications [52]. If the high active DMAEMA-based pILs were made to a catalytic membrane, they might be used for the highly efficient membrane catalysis of epoxides. Nevertheless, pure DMAEMA-based pILs were brittle and (partial) soluble in water and other strong polar solutes. These properties will result in the instability of the prepared membranes. Sengupta et al. [53] synthesized a series of stable antibacterial polymeric ionic liquid membranes (PILMs) by copolymerization of ILs monomer, co-monomers (acrylonitrile/styrene), and crosslinking agent 1,4-divinylbenzene. Based on this idea, a kind of stable PILMs may be prepared for the membrane catalysis of the cycloaddition reactions of epoxides. In this study, a kind of crosslinked copolymerized PILMs was synthesized and used for the Absorption-Conversion process of epoxides. A series of DMAEMA-based IL monomers with different functional groups were synthesized. And then, the PILMs were prepared by copolymerizing the IL monomers with methyl methacrylate (MMA), ethyl acrylate (EA), and poly(ethylene glycol) dimethacrylate (PEGDMA, the crosslinking agent), to improve the strength, flexibility, and solubleness of PILMs. The effects of the functional group on the catalytic activity of PILMs for the cycloaddition reactions of epoxides were investigated by the traditional gas-liquid reaction. Afterward, the PILM with the highest activity was used to evaluate the absorption-conversion ability for the cycloaddition of propylene oxide (PO), by suspending the PILMs catalyst in the upper part of the reactor and completely separating with the liquid PO. Moreover, the influence of reaction pressure, time, and temperature were systematically studied to get the optimum reaction conditions. Furthermore, the recyclability of catalysts was evaluated. This work aims to explore the potential of PILMs to be used in membrane catalysis and the issues of PILMs needed to be improved in the future. Experimental and methods Materials 2-(dimethylamino) ethyl methacrylate, 2-bromoethanol, bromoethane, 1-bromopropane, 3‑bromo-1-propanol, 1-bromobutane, methyl methacrylate, ethyl acrylate, poly(ethylene glycol) dimethacrylate (PEGDMA, mean molecular weight of 600), methanol, ethanol, benzoin, polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP, mean molecular weight of 24,000), ethyl acetate and epoxides were analytic grade and procured from Aladdin Chemical Co. CO2 with a purity of 99.95% was purchased from Beijing Analytical Instrument Factory. All materials were used without further purification. Preparation of ILs and PILMs Synthesis of ILs The synthesis method of DMAEMA-based IL monomers was described in detail in a previous paper [42]. Here is a brief description of the synthesis procedure of a typical IL: [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br, as shown in Fig. 2 . DMAEMA and 2-bromoethanol were mixed with ethyl acetate in a round-bottom flask. The flask was then mounted into a Schlenk line system to replace the air in the flask with N2. After that, the mixture was reacted at 60 °C for 24 h. The liquid [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br gradually precipitated in the bottom of the flask as the reaction progressed. Afterward, the precipitated [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br was washed three times with ethyl acetate to obtain a white crystal-like product. The product was dried in vacuum at 60 °C for 24 h. Other monomers were prepared via a similar process. Preparation of PILMs and polymers of pure monomer A typical preparation procedure of PILMs was as follows: A mixture of monomers containing IL monomer (30 wt%), MMA (30 wt%), EA (10 wt%), and PEGDMA (30 wt%) was dissolved in methanol (50 wt% of monomer mixture), which contained PVP (10 wt% of monomer mixture) and benzoin (1 wt% of the monomer mixture, the photo-initiator). The methanol was used as the solvent, and the PVP was used as the pore-foaming agent. The solution was stirred and sonicated to mix each component thoroughly. After that, the transparent solution was cast into a Teflon mold with a glass cover. The mold was then placed under a UV light (365 nm) for 2 h. The solidified solution (PILM) was carefully peeled off from the mold and immersed in ethanol. The PILM was washed three times with 30 min of sonication in ethanol to remove the PVP and the unreacted monomers. The PILM was then dried in vacuum at 60 °C for 24 h. The preparation scheme is also depicted in Fig. 2. Besides, polymers of pure monomers were prepared via a similar method, except that the poly(methyl methacrylate) (pMMA), poly(ethyl acrylate) (pEA), and pILs were too brittle or soft to be peeled off as membranes. The active component and other properties of the prepared PILMs and polymers of pure monomers were shown in Table 1 . Typical procedures for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates Two methods were used to evaluate the catalytic activities of PILMs for the cyclic carbonate synthesis: the traditional gas-liquid reaction (GLR) and the absorption-conversion process (ACP), as shown in Fig. 3 . For a gas-liquid reaction, 28.6 mmol of epoxides and a certain amount of PILMs/polymers containing 0.319 mmol of ILs (based on the theoretical IL amount in Table 1) were added to a 25 mL high-pressure reactor. After that, the reactor was sealed and the air in it was replaced with CO2. Before heating, CO2 was filled in the reactor with an initial pressure of 1 MPa to keep the epoxides maintaining a liquid state. When the reactor reached the target temperature, the inlet valve was slowly opened to raise the pressure to the target value, and keep the valve open until the reaction finished. After that, the reactor was rapidly cooled down to 0 °C in an ice bash. The products could be directly collected with a pipette and analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) after the unreacted CO2 was slowly released. For an absorption-conversion process, the procedure was similar to that of the gas-liquid reaction, except that the PILM samples were hanging in the upper part of the reactor via a frame loader, and the epoxides can only react with CO2 in the gas phase. It means that the reaction only happens when the PILMs could absorb/adsorb the epoxide vapor and CO2. In addition, in the recyclability test, the swelled PILMs after reaction were collected on the filter paper, and washed 3 times with ethyl acetate and ethanol, respectively, to remove the PC and PO left in the PILMs. Then the PILMs were dried in the drying oven to remove the ethanol and H2O. The weight of the used PILMs usually reduced after the reaction. Therefore, the added PO amount was reduced as well, to keep the mass ratio of PO and PILMs. Characterization methods Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) tests (RT–700 °C) to were carried out using a TG-DTA6300 thermal analyzer (NSK Ltd., Japan) in the N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Elemental compositions (C/H/O/N) of the membrane samples were examined by Vario EL Cube elemental analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of samples were determined by a Nicolet 380 FT-IR Spectrometer with anhydrous KBr as the standard. The membrane surface morphology was measured using Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM, JSM6700F, JEOL). The BET tests were conducted using a Micromeritics porosimeter (ASAP-2020 HD88) to obtain the pore size and pore volume of the membranes. The yield and selectivity of cyclic carbonates were determined via Gas Chromatograph (GC) (Agilent 8890) with an FID detector. The swelling ratios of PILMs in different solvents were tested by measuring the sizes and weight before and after immersing them in solvents for 24 h. The swelling ratio (q) was defined as Eq. (1), and the swelling ratio of membrane area (q A) was defined as Eq. (2). In the meanwhile, the density of PILMs could be calculated by Eq. (3). (1) q = V a W 0 = W − W 0 ρ a W 0 (2) q A = A A 0 (3) ρ mem = W 0 A 0 * t mem Where q is the swelling ratio (mL/g), Va is the volume of absorbed liquid in equilibrium (mL), W 0 is the weight of the membrane sample before immersing them into solvents (g), W is the weight of the membrane sample after immersing into solvents for 24 h (g), ρ a is the density of the solvent (g/mL), A0 is the area of the membrane sample before immersing into solvents (mm2), A is the area of the membrane sample after immersing into solvents for 24 h (mm2), ρ mem is the density of the PILM sample (g/mL), t mem is the thickness of the membrane sample before immersing into solvents (mm). Results and discussion Characterization of ILs and PILMs The obtained PILMs were transparent flexible membranes with high strength in the dry state. As shown in Fig. 4 , a piece of MEM01 (active constituent: [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br) could hold on to at least a weight of 500 g. The pPEGDMA (self-polymerized product of poly(ethylene glycol) dimethacrylate) was also a transparent flexible membrane, but with low strength, which could break easily. The Poly01 (self-polymerized product of [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br) and pMMA (polymethylmethacrylate) were fragile solids with high strength, while the pEA (poly MMA) was a flexible gel-like polymer, with low strength. The Poly01 were soluble in water, while the pEA (polyethylacrylate) and pMMA were soluble in organic solvents, e.g. dimethyl formamide. The PILMs and pPEGDMA were insoluble in common solvents and just swelling in some solvents due to the crosslinking. The copolymerization of ILs, MMA, EA, and PEGDMA improved the strength, flexibility, and solubleness of PILMs, as we expected (Fig. 5 ). The thermal stability of the prepared PILM (MEM01) was studied using thermogravimetric analysis, compared with IL monomers and polymers of pure monomers. As shown in Fig. 6 , there are two decomposition stages for MEM01 around 260 °C and 400 °C. The first decomposition stage was ascribed to the partial decomposition of the pIL structure and pMMA structure. The second decomposition stage of MEM01 was mainly caused by the decomposition of pEA, pPEGDMA, and pMMA structure. The TG curve of MEM01 indicates that the MEM01 was stable under 200 °C, and the effective catalytic component starts to be pyrolyzed at 220 °C. Besides, the MEM01 and pPEGDMA were almost entirely pyrolyzed at 480 °C, while the TG curves of pMMA, pEA, and pILs maintain at about 6 wt% even at 700 °C. On the one hand, the PEGDMA contains abundant ether structures, which provide lots of O elements to promote the polymers to decompose into small molecule compounds, rather than coke. On the other, the crosslinking structures in MEM01 and pPEGDMA form a network structure of the carbon chain, which is beneficial to the decomposition. As shown in Fig. 6, the PILM sample (MEM01) exhibits most of the characteristic peaks of the polymers of pure monomers. The peak of the PILM at 3280 cm−1 was the vibration perks of OH (3500–3050 cm−1), which can be ascribed to the p [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br structure in MEM01. Due to all monomers containing the ester group (COO), there is a strong peak at 1730 cm−1 (C=O) for all materials. The peak of MEM01 at 1240 and 1140 cm−1 may be attributed to the stretching vibration of CO (1300–1000 cm−1) and CN (1350–1000 cm−1). The characteristic peak of aliphatic ether appears at 1106 cm−1 for pPEGDMA and MEM01. The characteristic peaks of C=C for [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br monomer disappeared for all polymers. The surface microtopography and structure of MEM01 and Poly01 (p [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br) were measured by SEM. As shown in Fig. 7 , both MEM01 and Poly01 exhibit a relatively dense structure, and no apparent macroporous structure was found. It indicated that the prepared membranes could avoid the gas leakage derived from the macropores. However, there were massive cracks in Poly01, which will cause great leakage and instability of the membrane reaction process. The cracks in Poly01 can be attributed to the brittleness of p [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br. It suggested that pure p [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br is not suitable for membrane preparation, owing to its inherent brittleness, which may be ascribed to the ionic structure and massive hydrogen bond in p [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br. Given that no macropore structure was observed in MEM01 and pILs, the BET tests were conducted for dry MEM01 and Poly01 to obtain the micropore properties of MEM01 and pILs. As shown in Table 2 , the pore volumes (BJH desorption) of MEM01 and Poly01 were 0.0023 and 0.0015 cm3/g, respectively. It suggested that both MEM01 and Poly01 were almost materials without pores. Unfortunately, the pore-foaming agents PVP and methanol did not leave behind any pores in PILMs, which did not conform to our expectations. The imporous structure of PILMs should result in a poor catalytic performance for the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides and CO2. However, the PILMs exhibited excellent carbonate yields even without stirring, which will be discussed in later sections. Therefore, we conjectured the PVP and methanol indeed had left pores in PILMs, but the pores disappeared after PVP/methanol were removed, due to the shrinkage of PILMs. To verify this conjecture, we investigated the swelling properties of PILMs in different solvents. The swelling properties of PILMs were excellent, which may improve the catalytic activities for cycloaddition reactions. As shown in Fig. 8 , the swelling ratios of MEM01 in different solvents were different. The swelling ratios of MEM01 in polar solvents were high, such as PC and H2O. The swelling ratio of MEM01 in PC was 1.71 mL/g, which meant that 1 g of MEM01 could absorb 1.71 mL of PC. The density of MEM01 was about 1.84 g/mL, which meant 1 mL of MEM01 could absorb about 3 mL of PC. The value of 1.71 mL/g was 700 times larger than the pore volume of MEM01 (0.0023 mL/g). It suggested that dry PILMs and “wet” PILMs had different pore structures. The shrinkage of PILMs makes the abundant pores turn into a “hidden state”. When the PILMs were contacted with solvent and swelled, abundant micro catalytic environments would form. Nevertheless, the strength of the swelled MEM01 was deficient, resulting in the swelled MEM01 being easily damaged. Catalytic evaluation of PILMs and polymers of pure monomers The catalytic activities of the as-prepared PILMs and polymers with different functional groups were evaluated with the PO via the gas-liquid reaction. As shown in Table 3 , PO can hardly be converted to PC without catalysts (entry 1), and the catalytic activity of pMMA/pEA/pPEGDMA is too low to be detected (entry 3). For the same catalytic component: [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br (entry 2, 4, 5, and 6), the IL monomer exhibited the highest catalytic activity, while the fragment-like polymer of the pure IL monomer exhibited the lowest catalytic activity. The conversion of PO in entry 2 was almost the same as that in the work of Ying et al. [42], which implied that the addition of MMA, EA, and PEGDMA had little effect on the conversion of PO. The [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br is a homogeneous catalyst and can be evenly distributed in the PO/PC, which results in the high catalytic activity of the IL monomer. However, when the [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br was polymerized to form the fragment-like Poly01, the catalytic activity decreased greatly, and the conversion of PO reduced from 99.3% to 23.0%. Because the p [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br in this work can hardly be dissolved in PO/PC, and the fragment-like p [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br exhibits a relatively low pore volume (0.0015 cm3/g). The internal catalytic sites of p [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br can hardly contact the PO and CO2 molecules. Therefore, when the fragment-like p [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br was ground into powders with a mean size of 2 µm, the PO conversion increased from 23.0% to 46.8% (about 2 times). Even so, the catalytic activity of the powder-like p [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br was deficient compared with that in the work of Ying et al. [42] (PO conversion of 96.2%). Owing to the high concentration of monomers in the solution, the p [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br in this work formed large aggregates, which can hardly disperse in PC/PO. In comparison, p [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br in Ying's work was polymerized in a solution with quite low IL concentration, which resulted in powder-like pILs with an aggregate size of ∼110 nm. Nevertheless, even though the MEM01 was also a fragment-like solid, the catalytic activity of MEM01 was close to that of the IL monomer. The PO conversion in entry 6 was 98.0%, which was just 1.3% smaller than that of the IL monomer. This phenomenon may be ascribed to the dispersive catalytic sites (due to the co-monomers), the “hidden” micropores in PILMs, and the excellent swelling ability of PILMs in PC/PO. Above all, the crosslinking copolymerization of IL monomers and co-monomers not only improved the mechanical properties of PILMs but also maintained the high catalytic activity of IL monomers for PILMs. The influence of the functional groups in cations on the catalytic activity can be observed from entries 6 to 10. The cations in PILM with hydroxyl groups (MEM01 and MEM03) exhibited higher catalytic activity than that with merely aliphatic chains. The synergistic effect of the hydroxyl group and the Br– could greatly enhance the catalytic activities of ILs [30,35]. The difference in activity between MEM01 and MEM03 might be ascribed to the difference in alkyl chain lengths. From entries 6, 11, and 12, the influence of anions on the activities can be observed. The anion with higher nucleophilicity showed higher catalytic activity. Therefore, the PO conversion of MEM07 (I −) was 100%, and that of MEM06 (Cl−) was only 62.9%. However, I − is unstable and easy to be reduced to I2, which would make the catalyst deactivated. Therefore, the Br− presented a better overall performance. Moreover, by comparing MEM01 with MEM08, it can be found that the DMAEMA structure showed higher catalytic activity than that of vinyl imidazole. This phenomenon might be attributed to the hydrophobicity of ester groups in DMAEMA, which may induce a better dispersion of active hydroxyl groups, and prevent the over aggregation of active sites. Among all the prepared PILMs, MEM01 exhibited the best catalytic performance: PO conversion of 98.0% and selectivity of 99.9% under conditions of 110 °C, 2.5 MPa, 3 h, and catalyst dosage of 1.1% (mol). To sum up, PILMs with the active component of [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br exhibited the best catalytic activity, which was close to that of the corresponding monomer. Therefore, MEM01 was used as the optimal PILMs in further study. Catalytic evaluation of PILMs via absorption-conversion process As shown in Table 4 , the catalyst performance in the absorption-conversion process (ACP) was lower than that in the gas-liquid reaction. It is reasonable because the catalysts were utterly separated from the liquid PO in the ACP. The slow agitation (250 rpm) in the bottom liquid can hardly affect the gas flow of the upper gas phase. It meant that the PO could only react with CO2 via self-diffusion in the gas state (before absorption/adsorption). Even so, the PO conversion of MEM01 via the ACP was 87.3%, which was merely 10.7% smaller than that via the GLR. It suggested that the as-prepared PILMs can efficiently catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of PO under the harsh condition of only gas-state contact. The small PO conversion of MEM01 via the ACP might be ascribed to the smaller PO concentration in the gas phase at the late stage of the reaction, since most of the PO was converted to PC and the partial pressure of PO in the gas phase decreased continuously as the reaction progress. However, as for the Poly01, the PO conversion was only 3.1% for the ACP case, about 20% smaller than that of the GLR. It implied that the fragment-like Poly01 could hardly catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of PO via the gas state, due to the small pore volume of Poly01. In short, the excellent swelling ability of as-prepared PILMs resulted in the ability to catalyze the gas-state PO and CO2 efficiently. To evaluate the catalytic performance of PILMs via the ACP in different reaction conditions, we investigated the influences of temperature, reaction time, and pressure on the PC yields and compared them with the results via the GLR. The MEM01 was selected as the model catalyst, and the results were shown in Fig. 9 . The effect of temperature can be seen in Fig. 9(a): the PC yields increased as the temperature increased for both the ACP and GLR. Nevertheless, the PC yields via the ACP were lower than that via the GLR at the same temperature. On the one hand, the “macro reaction environment” in the ACP was harsh, since PO and CO2 could only contact MEM01 via diffusion. On the other, the PO concentration in the gas phase was affected by two factors: the PO vapor pressure and the concentration of PO in the liquid phase. The increase in temperature can improve the reaction rate. In the meantime, the initial partial pressure of PO increased as the temperature increased, as shown in Fig. 9(a). (The PO concentration can be represented by the initial partial pressure of PO.) At 100 °C, the PC yield via the GLR was 90.2%, while that was 54.5% for the ACP. The significant difference in yields might be ascribed to the low initial partial pressure of PO (26.6%). Furthermore, the PO concentration in the liquid phase decreased continually, since PO was converted to PC and the obtained PC returned to the liquid phase as liquid drops from the MEM01 samples at the top of the reactor. For instance, the yield via the ACP at 110 °C was 87.3%, and the partial pressure of PO was reduced to about 1/10 of the initial value (33.4%). An additional reaction time of 2 h could only make the yield increase to 94.8% (Fig. 9(b)). The low PO concentration in the gas phase is a key factor restricting the reaction rate of the ACP in this work. Nevertheless, the poor “macro reaction environment” implied the high catalytic activity of the “microenvironment” in PILMs. As shown in Fig. 9(b), the PC yields increased as the reaction time increased for both the ACP and GLR. It was worth noting that the yields in the first hour were already a considerable value, and the reaction rates in the later stage were very slow for both the ACP and GLR. It indicated that the conversion of low concentration PO is a key factor affecting the cycloaddition reaction. The influences of reaction pressure on the PC yields were different for the ACP and GLR. The pressure had little effect on the PC yield from 1.5 MPa to 4.5 MPa in the GLR. However, the PC yield via the ACP increased at first and then decreased as the pressure increased. This phenomenon was ascribed to the change in PO partial pressure. When the PO partial pressure was higher than 50%, the CO2 concentration was low, which was unfavorable for the reaction. When the total pressure was too high, the PO partial pressure was low and it was more difficult for the PO to evaporate into the gas phase. In summary, the optimal reaction conditions were 110 °C, 3 h, 1.5 MPa for GLR, and 120 °C, 3 h, 2.5 MPa for the ACP. Catalytic suitability and recyclability studies of PILMs The catalytic suitability of PILMs for different epoxides was investigated via the GLR and ACP with MEM01 at 110 °C, 3 h, and 2.5 MPa. As shown in Table 5 , MEM01 exhibited good catalytic suitability for epoxides. The conversions of EO, PO, epichlorohydrin, and styrene oxide were higher than 90%. The conversion of isobutylene oxide was a little small, which was 63.8%. Nevertheless, the conversion of cyclohexene oxide was only 35.1%. The low conversions of isobutylene oxide and cyclohexene oxide might be ascribed to the steric hindrance. In a word, PILMs exhibited good suitability for different epoxides to convert to valuable carbonates. Moreover, the conversion of EO via the ACP was the same as that of GLR, which suggested that the activity of EO was higher than PO, and EO was suitable for the absorption-conversion process. Recycle tests of MEM01 were conducted via the GLR and ACP at 2.5 MPa, 3 h, and 110/130 °C. As shown in Fig. 10 (a), the recyclability of MEM01 via GLR was very poor. The PO conversion reduced a little in the first 3 runs and decreased sharply in the later runs. On the contrary, the recyclability of MEM01 via the ACP was acceptable, as shown in Fig. 10(b) and (c). The PO conversion was reduced in the first several runs but maintained the same values in the later runs. The decrease in PO conversion might be attributed to the dissolution of unreacted IL monomer and pILs of small molecular weight. Therefore, the elemental analysis of MEM01 before and after 7 runs was measured. As shown in Table 6 , the original MEM01 exhibited an IL amount of 1.26 mmol/g, which was slightly higher than the expected value (1.06 mmol/g). This could result from the unreacted IL monomers and PVP in PILMs, which were not completely washed after 3 times of sonication. Hence, the washing method needed to improve in further studies. The IL amount was 1.01 mmol/g for MEM01 after 7 runs via the ACP, while it was 0.42 mmol/g for MEM01 after 7 runs via GLR. The swelled PILMs were soft membranes with lower tensile strength. The agitation in the liquid phase in the GLR might destroy the catalytic structures in swelled PILMs. Nevertheless, the swelled PILMs were “intact” in the ACP, therefore the catalytic activities were maintained. Possible mechanism The chemical mechanism of the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides catalyzed by functional pILs was well discussed in the work of Ying et al. [42], which involved the hydrogen bond between PO and PILs, as well as the nucleophilic halide ions. Here we focused on the physical mechanism of why PILMs could efficiently catalyze the cycloaddition of PO/EO via the ACP, which was a quite poor “macro reaction environment”. As shown in Fig. 11 , the dry PILMs were “shrunken” at the beginning of the reaction, and the PO slowly got into the CO2 phase via vaporization. As discussed in section 3.1, the PILMs could absorb PO and swell into membranes with abundant pores. Although the absorption of PO and CO2 from gas was a slow process, the PILMs would act like a sponge to store abundant liquid-state mixtures of PO and CO2. The shrunken catalytic network in PILMs would turn into a dilatant and soft catalytic network, which was surrounded by PO and CO2. Therefore, the PO and CO2 could be efficiently converted to PC in this microenvironment. The obtained PC could make the swelling rate of PILMs even larger. When high enough PC was obtained, the excess PC (which might contain a little PO) would form small drops and go back to the liquid phase. In the meantime, PO in liquid continually turns into PO vapor. However, in the later stage of the ACP, the PO concentration in the liquid phase was minimal. Therefore, the vaporization and rection of the PO would slow down. In short, the swelling ability endowed PILMs with high catalytic activity in the ACP. Conclusion In this work, a series of DMAEMA-based IL monomers with different functional groups were synthesized and copolymerized with MMA/EA/PEGDMA to prepare highly active PILMs for the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides and CO2. The synergistic effect of the hydroxyl group and the Br– in DMAEMA base IL monomers gave PILMs an abundant highly catalytic active site. Among the eight different PILMs, MEM01 (based on [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br) exhibited the optimal performance for the conversion of PO (98.0%). Moreover, the PO conversion of MEM01 via the ACP was 87.3%, while it was only 3.1% for Poly01 (pure pILs). The excellent catalytic activities of PILMs can be attributed to the highly dispersed active sites in PILMs and the superb swelling ability of PILMs. The dry PILMs could absorb the PO vapor, which resulted in the swelling of PILMs. Therefore, the enlarged pores in PILMs turned to abundant active catalytic environments to catch the PO vapor and CO2 to convert to PC. The PILMs exhibited good catalytic suitability for different epoxides. And the recyclability of PILMs via the ACP was acceptable, except for a little decrease owing to the unwashed small molecules. The influences of reaction conditions on the PC yields in the ACP were also investigated, and it was found that pressure played a dual role in the ACP. In short, PILMs were an excellent catalytic membraned for cycloaddition reactions of epoxides, and the stability and strength in swelling state need to improve in further studies. coredata.dc:description: Polymeric ionic liquid membranes (PILMs) were prepared by photo-initiated polymerization of DMAEMA-based ionic liquids (ILs) and co-monomers for the conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates. The influences of functional groups and anions were investigated to find the optimal ionic liquid monomer. The PILM based on [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br exhibited the highest propyl carbonate (PC) yield (98%), which was close to that of the [DMAEMA-EtOH]Br monomer. Moreover, the PILMs can catalyze the gas state propylene oxide (PO) and CO2 into PC with a PO conversion of 87.3%, while the PO conversion of the pure polymeric ionic liquids was only 3.1% for gas state PO. The excellent catalytic activity can be attributed to the highly active catalytic sites and superb swelling ability of PILMs. The dry PILMs could absorb the PO vapor and swell into membranes with abundant pores, which contained plentiful active sites to catalyze PO and CO2 to PC efficiently.
coredata.dc:title: Polymeric ionic liquid membranes for the absorption-conversion of CO2 and epoxides into cyclic carbonates
